author: Floedekartofler
body:
Look at charts leading up to the Dot Com bubble.

Cisco, Microsoft, Amazon all took many years to recover after the bubble burst. They are obviously legit companies. Also worth considering are companies like Doubleclick, Akamai and Yahoo, that weren't bad companies, just wasn't worth anything near their 2000 valuation.

Cisco is the best example, because Microsoft and Amazon weren't that overvalued in 2001. It still hasn't recovered in stock price, though it's probably made up for that through dividends in the last 20 years. It had a PE ratio of \~200 in comparison to the PE ratio of \~1200 Tesla has.

We'll see how it goes, but Tesla definitely has a lot to live up to.

author: MrDeath2000
body: Palo Alto, zscaler and Akamai.

author: HeGotTheWholeVillage
body: They are very talented, but the top guys at Verizon, Akamai, and Cloudflare are probably just as good technical talent, but have other products to offer their customers.

author: pxrage
body:
I don't know if this is true. Fastly has no moat, they can't compete with free tier CloudFlare on the bottom line and the top line can't compete with Akamai. 

So I'm unsure where their growth opportunities are.

author: quarky_uk
body:
Work in IT.

CRWD - Dealt with them in Feb, but their sales guy was an arrogant slimy piece of shit so didn't buy shares (Stupid, nonsense reason).

MSFT - Sticky (difficult to get rid of), bought shares.

AMZN - See MS (although bought way too late).

VMW - Love their products but never bought shares because it has been obvious since at least 4/5 years ago that change was coming, probably faster than VMware could change.

ORCL - Spit. Would never willingly use, or buy shares in.

SAP - Some stickyness in business, so have bought a small number in the past.

&#x200B;

Others - NET, AKAM, CTSH, OTKA, CRM are all ones that I considered but didn't buy, or didn't buy early enough. Still, all a learning curve!

No point in having regrets but I should have bought AMZN and CRWD a long time ago.

author: thug_funnie
body: You’re really looking at it wrong. It’s not a ranking. It‘s just market cap. Crowd strike, Zscaler, Enphase, StoneCo, Akamai, Solar Edge, First Solar, Etsy, Roku are all in QQQJ. I invest in QQQ as well but forgive me if I don’t think the Apples and Microsofts of the world have the headroom to deliver the gains these next companies can. Top 100 doesn’t mean all winners either, guy. And honestly you sound you think the next 100 are pennys stocks with a “shot” at hitting. These are large, mature, for the most part successful companies that just happen to not be worth hundreds of billions... yet.

author: AwkwardBaygull
body: Lotto Tix:::: THiccccCA' ticka' (merger announced) ... GMHI merging this Thurs/Fri ... T'DACk stacks (better than DKNG)... and there is the new COVID play,👂S. As for some solid companies you could probably make some money on with a few well-placed calls:::: PING, FLIR, FROG, TMO, AKAM, RTX, ATNM. And if you made it alllllllll the way here, I hear that the Discovery Chsnnel is coming out with some news beginning of this month about their own streaming service..... DISCA/K

author: Long_term_Andy
body:
AKAM stock looks p good, consistent revenue and earnings growth, trading at 20 PE for TTM. Says cloud and internet in description which means good industry.. 

Thinking about dropping 10k for a long term hold.. 

retards, yes or no do i pull trigger

author: MrDeath2000
body: Cisco doesn’t compete with Akamai or cloudflare. Their umbrella secure internet gateway is competing with zscaler, but it’s not really mature yet, but will be soon. On firewalls Cisco has been getting beaten by Palo Alto for a while.

author: MrDeath2000
body: Can you explain why cloudflare is better than Akamai?

author: sssmay
body:
Hi All. 

23. Started investing a month ago. Using Robinhood for stocks and then I have fidelity for a 401k, Roth IRA (also just started) and regular brokerage with them as well. Planning to keep only ETFs/index funds (maybe mutual funds?) in Fidelity 

I'm thinking of putting probably 500-1000 a month into my portfolio each month. (Want to keep some cash in the bank since I'm also planning a wedding, nothing too extravagant but it feels safe to have the cash on hand)

Here's my Robinhood breakdown: (rounded since some are partial shares). About $3200 invested and $400 in cash.

SQ - 2
MSFT - 1
CRWD - ~2.4
PYPL - 1
PLTR - 9
MA - 1
OKTA - 1
GOOGL - .03 (just throw like 10-20$ on this at a time)
CRM - 1 (bought on the post slack dip)
AAPL - 2
AKAM - 1
SPLK - 1
DAL - 2

Looking to get NET, ZS, DIS, WH, RYCEY

My goals are growth. Should I just keep investing in what I have? Or also look at other stocks? 

Also, my friend says I made a mistake using Robinhood because they aren't backed by a bank. But I read that they were SPIC insured for upto $250k which is about the same as being FDIC insured right?

author: always_learning_69
body:
point well received, disagreement makes a market.

with consistent 8% qoq, revenue would double in 10 years. stock price could stay flat and it'd still be at a high 31x P/S 10 years from now.

looks like market cap has doubled in the past 3 months with a doubling of the P/S ratio over that time. I agree that it's a solid business (although does seem to have competitors w/ fastly akamai aws etc) but I'd need to know more to justify current valuation

author: slumdungo
body: If we are still calling Akamai a CDN, Cloudflare is a CDN.

author: BenjaminFernwood
body:
Basically.

>It's as if we have already attributed everything we could imagine could happen...

[u/Henkss](https://www.reddit.com/user/Henkss/), that's approximately how I would describe what the market does to a newcomer and one of the many reasons growth/tech trades like long-duration instruments.

**It comes with extremely high risks.** Any change in rates or yield curve, credit-worthiness, forecast revisions, extra competitors, raw material/labor price change, geopolitical event, GLOBAL SUPPLY-CHAIN-DISRUPTING PANDEMIC STATUS, etc. has the risk of changing expectations for 5-10 years out---upside and downside risk.

From a fundamental perspective, investors/gamblers taking that kind of risk should have extremely high expectations. It just so happens TSLA has rewarded us a lot of the time. Many companies do not reward.

It reminds me when Tom Leighton's company Akamai went public in the late 90s. AKAM was the next big thing for the internet. Stock price fucking flew and AKAM was doing brilliant things, but what happens to even an innovative company like that when every fly-by-night dot.com was going under and panicked money and leverage was exiting the market?

Also, fundamental considerations completely ignore psychological and technical reasons TSLA is where it is. My three cents.

author: cardiffgiantthe1st
body: [https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/covaxin-covid-19-vaccine-shows-long-term-antibody-responses-says-bharat-biotech-in-research-paper-2342763?amp=1&akamai-rum=off](https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/covaxin-covid-19-vaccine-shows-long-term-antibody-responses-says-bharat-biotech-in-research-paper-2342763?amp=1&akamai-rum=off)

author: ninkorn
body:
On the one hand, he says, a deal could make strategic sense and help Cisco expand its reach in “edge cloud” computing, and could help Fastly accelerate growth and broaden its security capabilities. But Cisco has said it is not looking to do large M&A deals right now,

Fish also thinks that Cisco is more strategically aligned with others in the content delivery network market, including Akamai Technologies (AKAM). He asserts that Cisco is using Akamai for web-delivery of services, and says that “the two have a strong partnership.”

“While we are not outright dismissing the possibility… we lean toward this being improbable,” Fish writes.

Both Cisco and Fastly on Tuesday declined to comment, citing their policies of not responding to rumors.

author: devereaux
body:
This FSLY pump is based on nothing real.

That analyst more or less said "Cisco could hypothetically buy them, but doesn't want to and Akamai would make way more sense anyway, and I don't think it would happen"

But people hear "Ooh FSLY buyout"

author: TAOW
body: rofl Akamai. That's like me shopping at Walmart instead of Whole Foods
